To M
r
Secre
t
Oc
t
30. 90

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 30 Octo
b
To M
r
Secretary
It may please yo
r
H. to be adv
r
tized
t
yo
r
l
re
by
syvall
of
the 25 of Septemb
r
came to my hand
but yesterday w
ch
is more
then a moneth since yt was written. The matt
r
of
Groenighen
was
nev
r
oth
r
wise by him then in ge
nal
l termes im
ted unto mee, & w
th
out
any mention of those gentlemen of
Fryse
that sett him a worke
whose names yf I had knowen as yt is an exployt that requires
expedition, so I should have sought
e meanes before this time
to have knowen both
e quality of
e
sons and also their
credit w
th
oth
r
such requesyt point
as conc
r
nd a matter of that
moment. For there ar nomb
rs
in these countreys that indevour an
innovation of
e state upon pretences of being devoted to hir
Ma
tye
wh
r
as yt is apparent in a great many
t
yt rather
ceedeth
of their private desyr to bee revenged up
o
theyr statesmen, then
of any extraordinary zeale to
e common cause against
e
ennemy. But what course may best be tak
e
for furdering
e motion of Groenighen I will so consyd
r
as yo
r
H. hath writen
and walke so warely as I trust hir Ma
ty
wilbe pleased w
th
my doing
In
e meane tyme as yo
r
H hath writen so I have
suaded still w
th
those w
th
whom I have delt that hir Ma
ty
in regard of hir manifold burdens oth
r
wise will not ent
r
into
any charge about this entreprise. If
count Hollock
have any
such intelligence w
th
those of Groenghen as hir Hig
nes
is
informed yt hath bin caried so secretly that I have not heard
yt reported, howbeyt ther is likelyhode of yt for
t
he sojourned
in
Embden
&
haps had conference w
th
those
t
im
ted yt
to mee. w
ch
I suppose his l
re
s to hir Ma
ty
will signify
The matche between him &
e
Countesse of Bueren
ys gen
r
ally
sayd to be concluded. Yo
r
H. meaning about
e Townes of
Zeeland
t
have made some secret offer to hir Ma
tye
I do not well conceave
for
t
no lett
r
of mine hath made such mention, neith
r
hath any
man heer im
ted any such matt
r
unto mee. For I have alwaies
to my uttermost disswaded
t
course as well for
t
yt will breed
an Example of dangerous consequence as because I see so littel
trust to be reposed in any of all
e
mises of these discontented
sons. By
syvall & some oth
rs
I have hard
t
those of Fryse
were purposed to make an offer of
e Souverainty of theyr
offer
Province
to hir Ma
ty
. But in truth I could nev
r
ceave that there was (
some few
ticul
r
sons excepted) any such inclincation yn the
cheifest of
e State. for myne owne
te I have alwaies laboured
to [winne] as many from that conceat as by way of communication I
have found [addicted] unto yt. And I do yt
e rather for
t
I was
nev
r
yet in a better hope of a good correspondence between
these countreys & hir Ma
tyes
people then I am at this present.
What my care hath bin yn that behalf & what meanes &
speeches I have used to
e
Counsell
heer to
Count Maurice
to
e rest of
e Counts & likewise to those English Captaines
t
fol.165v
have bin employed in
e late services, & what courteous
ent
r
tainement hath insued upon yt both toward
S
r
Francis Vere
& all
e English Capt. & soul
d
, & how
e good liking of all
hand
hath continued ev
r
since I take no pleasure to report my
self, but this counsell doth afford mee many thank
& S
r
Francis Vere, ys a witnes that w
th
out my spetiall endevours in
divers respect
the state of these Countreys had bin far oth
r
then yt is, w
ch
I am
e more willing at this p
nt
to cause
in some sort to be knowen unto yo
r
H. to th'end yo
w
might stand fully
assured that I am alwaies an Ennemy to all such practises
as tend directly or indirectly to
e breach of
e union between hir
Ma
ty
& this people. It is accorded by
e
States of Holland
t
e English foote comp
s
w
th
S
r
Francis Vere shalbe dispersed in
e
garrison in
Dordrecht,
Rotterdam,
Delft
& any oth
r
of
e best
townes of Holland & in lieu of those band
that were drawen
forth of
Flushing
and
Oostend
by squadrons w
ch
are retourned
they desire & to
t
effect have writen to
e Gov
r
no
rs
of those townes
that there may from duch towne an entier company be sent hether
The late controv
r
sy risen betwene the Townes of North Holland
is accorded by mediation of
e states &
Count Maurice.
Like
the muteny of
liefkens Hoeck
is qualified by those of Zeland
w
th
c
r
taine moneths pay & oth
r
small contentment
, w
ch
kinde of
good usage hath
voked a great
te of
e souldiers in
Lillo
to
e like alteration, intending to have slain theyr Governo
r
&
other officers. But theyr purpose was discovered to
e Governo
r
&
e Chief conspirato
rs
app
r
hended up
o
yt. In effect there is
gen
r
all disc
o
tentment growen in all
e garrisons of Zeland by
reason of theyr paye w
ch
I think count Maurice will go in
son [to]
endevour to appease. The souldiers of
Schenck
sconse are become
so mutinous, that wee ar almost out of all hope that they
will be retayned. Wh
r
of theyr accustomed slacknes in this place
hath bin a principall occasyon for had they sent at
e first
400
[ls]
st
rs
all had bin satisfyed. Wh
r
as now they demand theyr
full Count & reconing w
ch
is not thought to be so litle as 6000
Howbeyt yt is resolved heer
t
for avoyding
e perill & consequence
of such composition they will yeeld to no more but 12 monethes paye
for this present intending rath
r
to forgo
e fort &
e offer th
r
of they had
comitted to c
r
taine fytt
sons whom they have instructed w
th
all
convenient
suasyon to drawe th
e
from theyr disloyalty. Yt is knowen
that
e Counsell of
Cleve
doth practize to buy the place for th
e
selves
w
ch
many men dout they will obteyn for
t
e chiefe part of
e
souldiers doth consist of Clevelanders.
Count William
of Frise, hath
wone of late by assault fr
o
e Ennemy a fort called
Salt camp
in
e territory of Groenighen. At
e very entraunce of Groenighen
deepe ov
r
against
Opslaeck,
a place of spetiall importance, wherby the
passage of vittail to
e Town of Groenighen is very much hindred, w
ch
I
think will be a help, for
fourmance of
e ent
r
prise before mentioned.
fol.166r
There ys no man yet named to
e Goverment of
Utrecht
but most men ar
suaded that yt wilbe conferred on
Count Maurice, & th
r
of mee think
there ys a common
good liking. The Ennemies forces that lay about
Berch
ar sayd to be de
ted & gon to winter in
e Duchye
of
Juliers
, wher
e brute goeth that both they spoyl
e
Countrey w
ch
is very fertill & are in many divisions among
th
e
selves. Uppon theyr de
ture
Count Oversteyn
&
e
Baron of
Potlits
have conducted into Berck 130 cart
laden w
th
vittail & oth
r
necessaries wh
r
by
e Town ys
vided for a
long time.
